I’m in a different moment of my personal life, too, traveling with my son, wife. I am enjoying these moments that will not come back.” So, basically, why force himself to stop? Why not try to see how much more his body can take? Why not hope to stay out there, doing what he’s done so well for so long, and maybe just give himself and his family — particularly his kid, still too young to remember what is happening yet — some memories to hold onto one day? “If I keep enjoying doing what I am doing and I feel myself competitive and healthy enough to enjoy, I want to keep going for a while,” Nadal explained. “I don’t know for how long, but I want to keep going for a while, because they are having fun, I am having fun, and I need to see — I need to give myself a little bit longer ... to see if my level is growing and my body is holding, and then let’s make a decision.” Makes perfect sense. Especially considering what both opponents took away from this latest performance, which was hardly up to Nadal’s career-long standards but did include the occasional patch of play that might have been good enough to get past a lesser obstacle than Zverev. The 27-year-old German is, after all, ranked No. 4, was the runner-up at the U.S. Open four years ago and the gold medalist at the Tokyo Olympics three years ago. Plus, he is coming off a clay title at the Italian Open and has been a semifinalist at Roland Garros each of the past three years. “I mean, I was not that far,” Nadal said. “That’s my feeling.” Zverev’s assessment: “If he stays healthy, he’s going to continue playing better.” Nadal sounded as though he agreed with that. He also asked for some time to make up his mind. “Give me two months ‘til the Olympics, and then let’s see if I am able to keep going or I say, ’OK, guys, it’s more than enough.’ Let’s see,” Nadal said Monday evening, after only his fourth loss in 116 French Open matches. “I mean, today is not a moment to analyze all these kind of things.” ___ Howard Fendrich has been the AP’s tennis writer since 2002. Find his stories at https://apnews.com/author/howard-fendrich and write to him at [email protected] ___ AP tennis: https://apnews.com/hub/tennis

title: My Week with Celia Holman Lee: Madcap fun for afternoon tea
creator: Frances Watkins
description: A CORPORATE event full of ‘Mad Hatters’ is not something you would expect to be attending, but I had the honour of doing so! The beautiful Savoy Hotel in Limerick city hosted a Mad Hatters Tea Party for their corporate clients and some of Limerick’s best known faces got an invite, too. It was a magn
content: A CORPORATE event full of ‘Mad Hatters’ is not something you would expect to be attending, but I had the honour of doing so! The beautiful Savoy Hotel in Limerick city hosted a Mad Hatters Tea Party for their corporate clients and some of Limerick’s best known faces got an invite, too. It was a magnificent event and so many wonderful people were in attendance, including journalist and former Limerick Leader reporter, Meghann Scully, who is always a joy to be around, and fashion designer Marion Murphy-Cooney, who I adore. The glitz and glam of the night was spectacular and upon arrival, we were treated to a lovely prosecco reception and goodie bags. DJ JP Dillon from Live95 was the MC for the evening, and what a wonderful job he did. Games such as pass the parcel, dancing competitions and guess the song, took place and the fun and laughs that were had were off the charts! Prizes included overnight stays in The Savoy and George, dinner in the Terrace, Hamptons, Vincenzo’s and of course, afternoon tea. Afternoon tea and Skellig gin cocktails were flowing throughout the evening and there was also entertainment from world renowned illusionist, LEON the magician, which partnered perfectly with the theme of the night. It was such a memorable event and one which lived up to its name, as the atmosphere was lighthearted and we were all giddy - which may have had something to do with the delicious cocktails on offer! I look forward to spending another fabulous evening in the five-star Savoy Hotel again soon -XxCelia

title: Take a trip down memory lane at Level Up Video Games
creator: Susan Shelly
description: New Kutztown store reflects the owner’s passion for gaming, collecting.
content: After years of collecting video games, systems and a large variety of related items, Paul Herr has channeled his passion for everything video-related into a business. Level Up Video Games opened recently at 13 East Main Street in Kutztown, recognizable by its nostalgia-steeped display window that features a vintage gaming system, Mario Brother figurines, a Nintendo poster, MAD magazines, a Polaroid camera, New Coke cans and a 1987 wall calendar. “I worked hard on that window,” said Herr, who is 55. “I wanted to give people a trip down memory lane.” A visit to the shop, which is known simply as Level Up, was a nostalgic experience for Brittany T., a graduate of Kutztown University who currently lives in Virginia. She spotted an early-model Sega console — the same version she and her brother shared as kids. “My mom entered a contest at the Coventry Mall (North Coventry Township, Chester County) and won a one-year subscription to Sega Channel,” recalled Brittany, who asked that her full name not be used due to concerns about it appearing on the Internet. “That was the first subscription that provided monthly access to about 30 games from the cable company.” She and her brother spent hours gaming, eagerly anticipating the release of every new video game. “That Sega started my whole journey,” said Brittany, who is now in her mid-30s. “I probably have more than 1,000 video games and still play all the time.” Brittany is not alone in her love for video games and related items, Herr said. The store has been busy since it opened with people looking to buy, sell, trade or simply reminisce about their gaming experiences. “I was surprised at how many college-aged kids came to the grand opening,” Herr said. “But I guess that everything old is new again.” Herr held the grand opening for Level Up Video Games on Saturday, May 4. Herr’s love of video games and gaming started when he was in high school in the 1980s and would visit his friends’ homes to play. “The Nintendo entertainment system came out and it was a big deal,” he said. “I didn’t have one at home, but some of my friends did and we played as much as we could.” Herr passed his love of gaming on to his four children, who range in age from 26 to 33. “The kids were little when I found a Nintendo 64 with four controllers,” he recalled. “I took it home and my kids fell in love with it. After that we started collecting anything we could find that was related to video games.” Herr planned to pass along the collection to his children and eight grandchildren, but eventually, with the support of his family, decided to open the store. “At the end of the day, it’s my kids and grandkids I’m doing this for,” Herr reflected. “I want them to be able to share my love of all this and experience the fun of it. It makes me happy that my 10-year-old grandson loves Zelda.” A part-time construction worker and owner of a cabinet shop, Herr was able to build and mount all the shelving and cabinets himself. Level Up is designed to showcase as many items as possible, with more collectibles being added all the time. “I took the whole collection and made a little museum in the store,” he said. Customers can browse among items including various models of Game Boys, Amiibo figurines, Pokémon cards, Super Mario mugs, headphones, lunch boxes, Pez dispensers, T-shirts and other video game-related gear. “I love when people come in and see something that gets them excited or nostalgic,” Herr said. “I want the store to be a fun place where people can stay as long as they want and explore and reminisce.” • Located at 13 E. Main St., Kutztown • Open Thursday, Friday and Saturday from noon until 8 p.m. • Connect on Facebook at Level Up Video Games • Call the shop at 484-926-3650

title: Steward Health Care failure in Massachusetts predicted by Catholic activists back in 2010
creator: Matthew Medsger
description: Steward Health Care failure in Massachusetts predicted by Catholic activists, back in 2010
content: Lawmakers were well warned more than a decade ago in advance of the current crisis surrounding several Bay State hospitals operated by now-bankrupt Steward Health Care, documents reviewed by the Herald show. The impending summer sale at auction of eight Massachusetts hospitals operated by the Dallas-based healthcare company is the inevitable result of selling the facilities formerly owned by non-profit Caritas Christi Health Care to an entity completely unsuited to running a hospital system, according to R.T. Neary, the former chairman of the Coalition to Save Catholic Health Care. Neary sat down with the Herald this month for an extended interview, during which he shared his written records and explained the efforts he and other hospital volunteers and patients made to warn anyone who would listen that selling hospitals to a venture capital firm would inevitably result in their failure. “The roots of Steward were highly tainted. In fact, they proved to be poisonous,” Neary said. Reporting in 2009 showed that Caritas Christi and the six hospitals it operated were doing better than they had the year before. Even during the financial crisis that marked the end of President George W. Bush’s Administration, and after posting a $20 million loss in the previous fiscal year, they would close out fiscal 2009 with $31 million in operating income. Fairly new to his job, then Caritas CEO Dr. Ralph de la Torre described his efforts to rebuild the struggling hospital system as a genuine tear-down operation; a complete restructuring of how the company managed its businesses. By 2010, credit agency Moody’s thought things were going so well at Caritas, that it upgraded their bond rating, not long after Standard and Poor’s had done the same while noting a 3.6% growth in revenues over the previous year. “Things were looking good,” Neary said. “They had one bad year — one — but things were turning around.” Neary, a former Caritas patient, donor, and volunteer, said that de la Torre seemed like the solution the struggling Catholic hospital system needed, right up until he became the problem. “Dr. Ralph de la Torre, masquerading behind medical credentials, proved to be a business venturer — and an unscrupulous one at that,” Neary said. After his hiring in 2008, his quick turnaround of the business side of the hospital systems, Neary said many in the Catholic community were taken by surprise when de la Torre announced venture capital firm Cerberus would buy the allegedly fiscally unsound hospital network and establish Steward Health Care Systems, LLC., with himself as CEO. “Cerberus is pleased to be making a long-term investment that will help ensure the viability and future success of the Caritas Christi health care system,” said W. Brett Ingersoll, co-director of private equity at Cerberus in a 2010 statement attached to the announcement of a $830 million plan to buy the hospital chain. The plan would need the approval of then Attorney General Martha Coakley and the state’s Department of Public Health, as well as the Archbishop of Boston. Cerberus, which had been in the news before the Caritas deal after their unsuccessful attempt to turn around automaker Chrysler , had never operated a hospital before. Coakley announced in June of 2010 the sale would be subject to six public hearings starting that month, but signaled she was open to the deal . “It’s no wonder,” Neary said. “Dr. de la Torre was raising money for her Senate campaign.” The Attorney General, according to public filings and contemporary reporting, had been the guest of honor at a fundraising event held at de la Torre’s Newton home the year before the Caritas sale was announced. The party had netted her campaign against now-former U.S. Sen. Scott Brown more than $34,000, and de la Torre and his wife each made the maximum personal donation of $2,400 to her . Coakley told the Herald in 2010 that she was thinking about the future when weighing the hospital sale. “What does this mean in the short run, and what does it mean five years, 10 years down the road,” she said then. The deal wasn’t worth the paper it was written on, Neary’s organization told her at length. Assertions about the hospital’s financial health, apparently dire, did not match their new credit ratings, he said. In writings to the AG, Neary expressed concern the system was destined to be torn apart and sold, bit by bit, until the hospitals couldn’t function. “Executives of Cerberus, as was done with GM, Chrysler and other of their organizations, will eliminate or severely curtail unprofitable divisions. With many hospital functions being seen in this category, we can be assured there will be changes,” he wrote to Coakley in a July 2010 letter. Neary, along with other faith-based organizations , wrote to Coakley dozens of times that summer, warning that Cerberus would run the hospitals into the ground. They wrote to the state’s Supreme Judicial Court — which eventually approved the sale — to Sen. Brown, then-Gov. Deval Patrick, the director of the FBI, the Archbishop, and the Pope. Their message, time and again, was the same. Approval of the sale, they wrote, would come “with a heavy monetary cost down the road for the citizenry.” The deal was eventually allowed to go through , at a final cost of $895 million. Neary, now 89-years-old and retired from his career as a high school teacher, was not surprised when it was announced earlier this month that Steward would file for bankruptcy and look to sell most of its dozens of hospitals, including the eight it now operates in Massachusetts. That was always their plan, he said. Steward’s downfall, first signaled this January when their landlords let it be known they were $50 million behind on their rent, could have been prevented, according to Neary. At the very least his letters, held now in a black binder and meticulously organized by date, serve as proof that he was right to be concerned, he said. Unfortunately, no one listened. “We warned them,” Neary said. “A venture capital firm should never have been allowed to buy a non-profit hospital system — a system built on the more than 100 years of patient and community donations. Steward’s hospitals will go up for auction at the end of June and bankruptcy proceedings are still ongoing while the company faces dozens of lawsuits from vendors and employees. Coakley did not return a request for comment.

title: Today on Pinstripe Alley - 5/28/24
creator: Jake Devin
content: After getting a day off on Memorial Day to wash away the taste of a loss to end the series in San Diego, the Yankees are back in action up the road in Anaheim. The Angels have had just as poor a season as you’d expect knowing they’d lost Shohei Ohtani, and they represent another good opportunity for the Yankees to win a series. It’ll be Nestor Cortes on the bump tonight against Griffin Canning to try and get the Yankees back in the win column. It’s another late start, so we’ll have plenty to keep you occupied on the site throughout the day. In the morning, I’ll preview the three games in Anaheim, while Peter runs through the games the Yankees’ rivals played on Monday. Also, Jeff writes the latest entry in the 1999 Yankees diary, and Esteban’s At-Bat of the Week features Gleyber Torres, turning things around. New York Yankees vs. Los Angeles Angels Time: 9:38 p.m. ET TV/Online: YES Network, Bally Sports West Radio: WFAN 660/101.9 FM Venue: Angel Stadium, Anaheim, CA 1. If the Yankees had to play a do-or-die game tomorrow, which of their healthy starters would you hand the ball to? 2. Anthony Volpe has racked up 2.6 fWAR so far, and projects to finish with 5.3 fWAR. Would you take the over or under on that number?

title: Explainer: Fabricators essential in producing local steel for Bills stadium project
description: Most of the companies in the state working on the steel beams for the Buffalo Bills new stadium project are custom steel fabricators. A fabricator takes the material from a steel mill and readies it for the worksite through the...
content: A ton of steel – roughly 25,000 tons – will be going into the new Buffalo Bills stadium. If this were another era, there’s a good chance most of it could come from steel mills in the Buffalo Niagara region. But those steel mills closed more than 40 years ago. In fact, there is little to no steel manufactured in mills in New York State anymore. Ironworkers assemble the steel frame of the new Bills stadium under construction in Orchard Park. There are at least 40 steel fabricators throughout New York, employing around 2,000 people, working on the project. That’s forcing the contractors building the $1.7 billion stadium to rely on steel made in other parts of the country for the massive stadium construction project. But state officials also note that there is still plenty of steel work being done by New York firms. They say about 60% of all the structural steel that will be used in building the stadium will be worked on in the state. That means a number of New York companies will play a role in the making, finishing and delivering of the steel used in the stadium, state officials said. But if there are few to no mills manufacturing steel left in the state, including in the once proud steelmaking Buffalo Niagara region, what does that 60% number touted by the state really mean? Essentially most of the companies in the state working on the steel beams for the stadium are custom steel fabricators. A fabricator takes the material from a steel mill and readies it for the worksite through the processes of cutting, bending, welding and assembling. They will take on tasks like figuring out where the bolt holes should be and building them into the steel. Fabricators play a critical role in a project of this size, said Brian Raff, vice president of sustainability for the nonprofit trade organization American Institute of Steel Construction, which represents both steel mills and fabricators. “Many times, the steel mills are only credited for this work, and I understand why that is because some people have never heard of structural steel fabricators, but their role is important in this project,” Raff said. “Most don’t understand the nuances of steelmaking.” The state is working with Cives Steel Co., a national firm headquartered in St. Lawrence, north of the Adirondacks, as the prime contractor for the steel fabrication work. Approximately 12,000 tons of steel – nearly half of what’s being used on the project – will be fabricated by Cives Steel. From the time we first heard of preliminary talks about a new Bills stadium, our team has been there to bring you news about the deal. Catch u... The company is among about a dozen fabricator facilities that are lined up for the stadium project. They also include JPW Structural Contracting in Syracuse and A&T Ironworks in New Rochelle. Local subcontractors working on the steel include Seneca Steel Erectors of West Seneca, Steel Tech Fabricators from Rochester, Huntress Painting of Niagara Falls and Interstate Steel Sales of Orchard Park. At least eight local unions representing laborers, carpenters, teamsters, engineers, plumbers, electricians and cement masons will be on the job while steel is being erected, state officials said. Additionally, Upstate Steel has been pursuing work on the stadium project after state economic development officials reversed their decision to exclude the Hamburg steelmaker from New York’s woman-owned business program. Led by Lauren Chmielowiec, the company’s president, Upstate Steel now operates a warehouse in an old Bethlehem Steel building. The steel these fabricators are working on is all being manufactured in the United States for one of the biggest construction projects ever in Western New York. “We wanted to see domestic steel, and we’re obviously looking for as much of the materials and labor to be as local as possible,” said Steven Ranalli, president of Erie County Stadium Corp., the state entity overseeing the project. About a year into the project, work is now being done on the second level of the new Bills stadium, continuing to rise from “the pit,” the deep hole that was dug to form its foundation. The steel is being used to build the skeleton of the open-air, 1.35 million-square-foot stadium that will seat over 60,000 fans and is expected to be completed before the start of the 2026 season. About a year into the project, work is now being done on the second level of the stadium, continuing to rise from “the pit,” the deep hole that was dug to form its foundation. Steel will go up level by level around the bowl, starting in the northwest corner of the stadium and proceeding to the southeast corner. The final level to be built will be level 5, which will consist of the stadium canopy 200 feet in the air. This summer, state officials expect about 1,500 workers a day will be on site as more steel goes up higher and some of the more detailed work gets underway. “These types of projects are a really big boost for the local economy and certainly New York’s economy,” Raff said. “And by employing all these people to support things like this stadium and critical infrastructure, I think steel fabrication contributes quite a bit to the local and state economies.” There are at least 40 steel fabricators throughout New York, employing around 2,000 people, and they work with many suppliers and other trades, creating additional jobs in these related fields, Raff said. That includes around 85 companies involved in painting the structural steel once it is fabricated, as well as others building in the columns or pillars on the beams, he added. By keeping steel fabrication local, there’s also savings on transportation costs and lowering emissions that come along with moving materials. “New York is a really big contributor to the steel construction environment,” Raff said. “We’re excited to see any high-profile project using structural steel so we’re following the stadium on the edge of our seat.” But overall steel production in New York isn’t what it used to be. These days, the state’s steel production is less than 1 million tons annually, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute. That pales in comparison with the nation’s leader in steel production, Indiana, which made more than 21 million tons of steel in 2022, and even the second highest steel producer, Ohio, with over 10 million tons of steel made that year. The steel being used at the stadium includes a green sustainability profile that makes this project environmentally friendly, Raff said. The production process, which no longer lives up to the trope of it being dingy and outdated, uses electric arc furnaces, emitting 75% less carbon dioxide than traditional methods at many foreign mills, he added. It contains mostly recycled material that comes from the steel of decommissioned bridges, buildings, appliances and automobiles. It gets melted down over and over and is continually made into new steel without any loss of durability or strength, Raff said. “It’s a really huge sustainability story for steel and a really good choice for this stadium,” Raff said. title: Housing for 100,000 people in limbo as construction projects stall
description: Elevated construction costs, a shortage of labour and a lack of off-the-plan buyers have lifted the number of stalled new dwellings that are already approved to over 37,000.
content: Copy link Copied Copy link Copied Subscribe to gift this article Gift 5 articles to anyone you choose each month when you subscribe. Already a subscriber? Login Construction of tens of thousands of approved dwellings that could provide housing for a city the size of Ballarat has been put on the backburner due to soaring building costs, labour shortages, a lack of sufficient pre-sales and concerns over builder failures, a new report by KPMG has found. Analysis of Australian Bureau of Statistics data by the firm’s urban economist Terry Rawnsley found that as of December 31, over 37,000 dwellings were approved but had not yet commenced construction, a 9 per cent increase on the five-year average. title: Athletics’ Brennan Milone Shows A Knack For Hitting
description: Brennan Milone's bat long intrigued the Athletics, who drafted him in 2022. He has proven to be an on-base machine in pro baThe post Athletics’ Brennan Milone Shows A Knack For Hitting appeared first on College Baseball, MLB Draft, Prospects - Baseball America.
content: From the time Brennan Milone started hitting in high school to draft day 2022, the Athletics watched him closely. “As a staff, we liked him a lot in high school,” A’s scouting director Eric Kubota said. “Our area scout, Jemel Spearman , really liked him and made sure a bunch of us saw him that spring. He’s always had a knack for hitting.” When Milone finished at Georgia’s Woodstock High, the Dodgers drafted him in the 28th round. He chose instead to attend South Carolina, then lost his freshman season to Covid. He returned as a sophomore in 2021 to play 38 games, but he hit just .216 with three homers. Milone transferred to the Oregon in 2022 and again started slugging, batting .337 with 12 homers in 60 games. “I kept an eye on him when he was at South Carolina and then was able to see him at Oregon,” Kubota said. “We were fortunate to have a history with him already. We thought he could hit, and his numbers backed it up, so we took a chance. I’m happy that things are going well so far.” 2 Hits, 2 Homers for the RockHounds! Brennan Milone with a solo shot! pic.twitter.com/S3dDRGCzof The A’s drafted Milone as a third baseman in the sixth round in 2022. Last year at two Class A levels, he hit .285/.398/.488 with 17 homers and 72 walks in 114 games. Through 40 games at Double-A Midland this year, the 23-year-old Milone hit .273/.368/.434 with five homers and 20 walks. “His bat has carried him to Double-A,” A’s farm director Ed Sprague said. “He’s really been an on-base guy as well. Power can be the last thing to come, and that will be the separator for him.” The biggest question for Milone will be position. A high school shortstop, he played third base and first base in college. He has played mostly first as a pro. “(Midland manager) Gregorio Petit says he can play third,” Sprague said. “It’s mostly about him gaining the confidence to do it.” A’s ACORNS — Injuries have slowed two of the Athletics’ top shortstop prospects. Double-A Midland’s Jacob Wilson went down with knee tendinitis after a torrid start to the season. Triple-A Las Vegas’ Max Muncy got hit in the hand and needed time off. — Righthander Cole Miller , drafted in the fourth round last year out of high school, continues to recover from Tommy John surgery he had this spring. Righthander Nathan Dettmer , a fifth-rounder from Texas A&M, has been sidelined by an elbow chip.

title: START THE WEEK OFF RIGHT: Crunch time: Embracing the cicada craze
description: Cicadas are all the buzz and the emergence of two broods simultaneously is a natural wonder not to be missed.
content: Cicadas are all the buzz and the emergence of two broods simultaneously is a natural wonder not to be missed. To embrace the cicada craze, people have been finding ways to make the most of this free and nutritious food source. Yes, you read that correctly ... cicadas can be eaten and taste good! They are related to shrimp and lobster so if you enjoy these, you may enjoy their land-dwelling relative. Bogdonas I had the chance to collaborate with my horticulture colleagues on a recipe tasting event in Springfield, Illinois, and the food was a huge hit. I was pleasantly surprised to discover that cooked cicadas taste and smell like asparagus with a hint of sesame. I encourage you to take advantage of the opportunity to try something new while supplies last. They provide nutritional value. Cicadas, like other edible insects, are rich in protein, unsaturated fat and contain a variety of vitamins and minerals. Specific nutrient values are dependent on factors such as species, diet, and developmental stage. When is the best time to find cicadas? Just after sunset cicadas can be found crawling up vertical surfaces (trees, fences, etc.). This is also a common time for them to molt their outer shell (teneral stage). Tenerals are white and considered best for eating because their adult shells have not hardened. After that happens, the wings and legs can be removed before cooking if desired. See recipe below for more information. Safety considerations before you chow down: Frozen cicadas can be stored in the freezer for up to a year for best quality. Remember to blanch (see steps on blanching below in step #2) for one minute before using in recipes. They can serve as a replacement for meat or as a healthy protein option added to baked goods. Cicada's can provide an alternative source of protein, such as on pizza. Ingredients: Directions: 1. Wash hands with soap and water. Preheat oven to 425°F. 2. To prepare cicadas: Remove frozen cicadas from freezer and de-wing (If using tenerals, you do not need to de-wing). After de-winging the cicadas, they must be blanched for a minute in boiling water (salting optional). This step will not only defrost the cicada, but it will also remove any unwanted dirt on their exterior, and kill any harmful pathogens found on and within the cicada. 3. Spoon pesto over the naan bread. Spread the mozzarella evenly over the pesto. Artfully arrange the sundried tomatoes and artichoke hearts over the cheese. Add the blanched and towel dried cicadas to the pizzas (8 on each). 4. Top with shredded parmesan and a drizzle of olive oil. Bake for 15 minutes, or until desired doneness. 5. Wait 17 years and repeat steps 1-4. Recipe adapted from The Eat-A-Bug Cookbook by David George Gordon Sources: Kristin Bogdonas is the Nutrition & Wellness Educator for University of Illinois Extension serving Henry, Mercer, Rock Island and Stark Counties. For more information, resources, and events, visit extension.illinois.edu/hmrs . Subscribe to our Daily Headlines newsletter.

title: Sri Lanka’s tea producers warn 70% wage hike will hit industry
creator: Cde
description: Sri Lanka’s tea producers warn 70% wage hike will hit industrySri Lanka orders 70% wage increase for tea workers, industry protests.The post Sri Lanka’s tea producers warn 70% wage hike will hit industry first appeared on The Dispatch.
content: Sri Lanka’s tea producers condemned a government order to increase wages by 70%, saying it would make their tea globally uncompetitive and reduce dollar earnings essential for the island nation to emerge from a financial crisis. The $1.3 billion industry produces popular Ceylon Tea and employs about 615,000 workers. The island annually exports about 95% of the 250 million kilos of tea it produces. The government has ordered worker salaries be increased to 1,700 rupees ($5.66) per day from 1,000 rupees, which the industry says will increase tea production costs by 45%. The fallout from Sri Lanka’s protracted financial crisis, caused by a severe shortfall of foreign exchange in 2022, has also hit the tea industry, quadrupling fertiliser, fuel and power costs, the Planters’ Association of Ceylon (PAoC) said. “This is unsustainable and unfair. This decision was made without proper consultation and will result in the quality of Sri Lanka’s tea declining,” PAoC spokesperson Roshan Rajadurai told reporters. “Sri Lanka’s key rivals, India and Kenya, have lower prices and higher productivity.” The industry must start paying the salary increase from next month, Sri Lanka’s Labour Ministry said on Sunday, warning that plantation companies refusing to comply could be taken over by the government. Implementing the wage hike will cost plantation companies an additional 35 billion rupees, the association said. Plantation companies and worker unions have been negotiating for months to increase salaries, which unions contend is essential as Sri Lanka’s financial crisis plunged around a quarter of the population into poverty in 2023. ($1 = 300.4000 Sri Lankan rupees) Via Reuters

title: Matthew Etzel Blazes Trail For Late-Round Orioles Picks
description: The Orioles drafted Matthew Etzel in the 10th round last year. He has done nothing but hit ever since.The post Matthew Etzel Blazes Trail For Late-Round Orioles Picks appeared first on College Baseball, MLB Draft, Prospects - Baseball America.
content: The Orioles’ recent player development success has been defined by the aptitude of their high draft picks. Outfielder Matthew Etzel might end up blazing the trail for later picks making an impact. The Orioles drafted him in the 10th round last year out of Southern Mississippi. He has done nothing but hit since signing. Through 40 games this season, Etzel hit .298/.389/.461 with four home runs and 23 stolen bases for High-A Aberdeen. “The hit tool itself is really elite,” Aberdeen hitting coach Zach Cole said. “He’s just really good at finding the barrel on any pitch types.” WAVE IT BYE-BYE! Matthew Etzel tacks on an insurance run with a solo homer of his own! IronBirds lead 4-0 in the 8th pic.twitter.com/bg57MosVuO Whether taken early in the draft or on the later side, Etzel has many of the traits the Orioles favor in their hitting prospects: athleticism, bat-to-ball ability and a knack for finding the barrel. Part of his developmental plan to further harness that is relatively common for players who can get to pitches all over the zone, with a focus on not swinging at pitches he can’t drive. “That will come with making better swing decisions in time as well—not to say his are poor,” Cole said. “But at times he can get exploited because he knows he has that good hit tool where he can just pepper one over there. “But as pitching continues to level up, as he grows levels, they’re going to be able to exploit that a little more and he might have to refine that.” High-A has typically been a place where that growth is solidified in the Orioles’ system in recent years. A challenging diet of pregame work focusing on different pitch shapes and movement profiles helps hitters develop plans on how to hit offerings of a quality level they may not see until the high minors. The success stories from that developmental track aren’t lost on anyone, from Gunnar Henderson and Colton Cowser to Coby Mayo . “We use a ton of examples from the past,” Cole said. “You’ve seen guys like Coby Mayo need to make some better decisions at the plate, just continuing to attack that.”

title: Do-nothing developers with building approvals worsen housing crisis
creator: The Herald's View
description: Attempts to tackle Sydney’s housing crisis are being undermined by the failure of developers to start work on projects that have building approval.
content: Attempts to tackle the nation’s housing crisis are being undermined by the failure to complete dwellings over the past five years. In Sydney, it is being exacerbated further by the failure of developers to even start work on projects that have been granted building approvals. In a curious juxtaposition, construction of thousands of new Sydney homes has stalled despite the city’s deepening rental crisis as soaring building costs, supply problems, tradesmen shortages and interest rates put residential projects on hold. The Herald’ s Matt Wade reports that more than 11,000 homes around Sydney were approved but not yet commenced in December, which was 8 per cent higher than the five-year December average. About 80 per cent of the total were townhouses and apartments, prime rental market properties. According to a new report by KPMG, the number of new dwellings approved across NSW but not commenced jumped from 13,765 in the March quarter of 2023 to 15,593 by the December quarter. Despite population increase fuelling the demands by both buyers and renters, dwelling construction has been hit by a perfect storm of constraints on activity. In the early days of the COVID-19 pandemic, supply chain disruptions significantly limited the sector’s ability to respond to increasing demand, which was partly linked to the HomeBuilder program for first home buyers and eligible owner-occupiers. Materials, fixtures and fittings, and skilled labour, especially in finishing trades, were in short supply and shipping delays significantly extended build timelines. Pandemic-related supply chain disruptions and competition for resources from other types of construction have pushed up prices significantly, by nearly 40 per cent since late 2019. Reserve Bank of Australia assistant governor Sarah Hunter, addressing a conference in Hobart earlier this month on housing market cycles in the building sector, said that the building industry had navigated the temporary disruption created by the pandemic but was now facing weaker demand and dwelling approvals were the lowest in decades. In Sydney, the rise in the number of projects approved but still on hold leads to the conclusion that some developers have delayed projects because of the relatively high cost of building when compared with the project’s returns. What’s to be done to liberate these lifelines to the housing crisis? Since coming to power, the Minns government has attempted to address the housing crisis by “rebalancing housing growth” across NSW with a focus on well-located homes close to transport, jobs and existing infrastructure. Eight Sydney transport hubs have been selected for accelerated rezoning aimed at delivering 47,800 new high and mid-rise homes and rezoned locations across NSW, allowing for 138,000 new homes to be created within 400 metres of metro or suburban rail stations and town centres. Minns has also pledged to change the rules to allow flat-building in all residential zonings. While welcome, most of these proposals could take up to 15 years to bear fruit. That is a long way off but the 11,000 plus homes put on hold by developers are a low-hanging and quick fix. Initiatives that streamline approvals and build processes will reduce costs and ultimately lift supply and the Minns government should consider what sort of leverage it can exert on recalcitrant developers to start work on the properties that have received building approvals. A suggestion from the mayor of North Sydney, Zoe Baker, that the Minns government could offer residential builders a financial guarantee to ensure approved projects are completed quickly is worthy of consideration. Such a proposal raises the possibility that developers could be persuaded to build additional social housing as part of the deal and has the advantage of incentive rather than big stick. Bevan Shields sends an exclusive newsletter to subscribers each week. Sign up to receive his Note from the Editor .

title: Yankees’ Ben Cowles Alters Routine And Sees Results
description: Shortstop Ben Cowles used his brief Triple-A time last year to inform the adjustments he needed to make. Now, the 2021 pick is thriving at Double-A.The post Yankees’ Ben Cowles Alters Routine And Sees Results appeared first on College Baseball, MLB Draft, Prospects - Baseball America.
content: At least so far, the impact of the Yankees’ 2021 draft class has been felt more in terms of who it has netted them in trades. Perhaps 24-year-old shortstop Ben Cowles will be the one to change that. The Yankees have traded six of their top nine picks from 2021, including first-rounder Trey Sweeney , second-rounder Brendan Beck and emerging ninth-rounder Chandler Champlain . Of those drafted in the first two days, only Brock Selvidge , Tyler Hardman , Will Warren and Cowles remain in the organization. While the righthander Warren got the majority of the attention this spring, it is Cowles, a 10th-rounder from Maryland, who remains on a steady track to the big leagues. The 6-foot, 180-pound Cowles has had a breakout start at Double-A Somerset. Through 43 games, he hit .320/.406/.527 with four home runs. According to Cowles, his brief stint at Triple-A Scranton/Wilkes-Barre last year, where he was sent for the last week of the season, showed him the adjustments necessary for the higher levels. “Just being able to experience that firsthand, where it was like, ‘Wow, my swing doesn’t play here. I have to change something.’ Going through those struggles helped me out a lot,” Cowles said. “I got the chance to talk to the Triple-A guys, and we went through my routine and things I could get better at. And I took that new routine and took it to the (Arizona) Fall League, and it worked out pretty well.” Primarily a shortstop, Cowles has also played second base and third base this season, just as he did in the AFL last year. That versatility could help make him a priority callup if the Yankees need emergency infield help.

title: My View: Once upon a time, it seemed like everything was free
description: The rest of the park was also free, including the Historical Society (now History Museum) and the Albright Art Gallery (now AKG).
content: Can you imagine? They want $20 for a 12-year-old kid to get into the zoo. Larry Beahan remembers when the Buffalo Zoo was free. When I was 12, the zoo was free for everyone. We kids lived close enough to walk to Delaware Park and we often visited the zoo, particularly in the summertime. We always checked on Eddy the chimp, the polar bears and the elephant. Watching the seals glide across their pool and leap out of the water onto a cement slab was a cooling, thrilling sight, almost as much of a thrill as watching the lion yawn on those hot summer days. One of my best memories is also one of the stupidest things I did as a kid. A few times, I took a book along to the zoo and when I tired of watching the animals, I climbed up the stone divider between the bear caves and lay down on the ledge above the polar bears to read in that secret, adventurous place. Thinking of it now, that adventure may be a good argument for pricing the zoo out of the range of a Buffalo News delivery boy, as I was then. The rest of the park was also free, including the Historical Society (now History Museum) and the Albright Art Gallery (now AKG). Sometimes we would walk the extra distance across the golf course and the Delaware Avenue bridge with the hope of seeing the apostles come marching out of the old mechanical clock in the Historical Society or view the dioramas of Seneca villages and the gun collection, sufficient to arm a rebellion. The art gallery with its statues and paintings was a wonder through which we wandered with big eyes and little understanding. Mom enrolled my sister, Marge, in watercolor classes there on Saturday mornings. I think that might even have been free. Saturday mornings we would ride the #23 streetcar, for 3 cents apiece, down Fillmore to Northampton. We’d get out there and walk past my Gramma’s house up to the Buffalo Museum of Science. It, too, was free, and we wandered the halls passing the Rosetta Stone, the giant four-story pendulum and the dodo bird, to mention just a few of the marvels. Then we would assemble in the museum auditorium for Mrs. Weyerhaeuser’s free story hour. She would never fail to entertain and probably to educate us, though we had no idea we were being educated. We topped the museum visit with a 5-cent serving of the best mashed potatoes and gravy in the world served in the cafeteria. We’d stop at Gramma’s on the way home for a baloney sandwich and a hug. But back to Delaware Park. There was a grove of chestnut trees to the left of the Jewett Parkway entrance. We collected a grocery bag full of nuts there every year. We made a game of stringing one on a shoelace and hitting it with another on a shoelace ; the winner survived the collision . A little further in that direction was a quarry. It was 15 or 20 feet deep, 100 or 200 yards long, lined with shrubs and small trees along a path. A stone bridge arched over it, for the convenience of golfers. We kids needed no bridge. We climbed the trees or the rocky cliffs themselves to ascend the quarry wall. It was a great disappointment when I returned to Buffalo after eight years away and discovered the quarry was filled in with debris from the Route 198 project. I wanted to bring my kids there for a taste of my youthful adventures. Neither bears nor entrance fees would have hindered us. title: Madison Area Community Events
description: Madison Area Community Events
content: MESA’s Food Pantry is looking for volunteers to help out three to four hours each week packing and unpacking groceries, stocking shelves, sorting food items, greeting clients. Several day or evening shifts available. Also drivers are needed Mondays and Wednesdays with a pick-up or large SUV to pick up boxes of food from area stores. Must be friendly, compassionate and reliable. Walking and light lifting required. Email volunteer@mesamadisonva.org for more info. The Literacy Council of Madison County is accepting used printer ink and toner cartridges at the office at 110 N. Main Street, Suite A, Madison. The cartridges will be recycled resulting in funds raised for the council. For after-hours deposit, place in the collection bin outside the door. Due to vendor restrictions, only HP and Canon inkjet and toner cartridges can be accepted. For more information, call 948-5514 or email info@madisonliteracy.org . Like to help people? Like to drive? Aging Together is seeking volunteer drivers. If you are seeking volunteer opportunities and would like to help older adults or those with disabilities get to doctor’s appointments, grocery stores, and more, contact Sarah Gillespie of Aging Together at sgillespie@agingtogether.org or (540) 505-5900. Volunteer drivers are needed in Culpeper, Madison and Orange. You decide your schedule and where you would like to volunteer. You can use your own vehicle, or you may choose to use an agency car. Fauquier Health offers a stroke support group which meets the second Wednesday of each month at noon in the Sycamore B Conference Room, 500 Hospital Drive, Warrenton. Join for an informational and supportive conservation about stroke recovery and all other factors that come into play for a family and community coming around a loved one who has experienced a stroke. The Madison County Historical Society’s Madison Museum in the Kemper Residence in the Town of Madison is open Tuesday, Thursday and Friday 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. The Mountain Museum at Criglersville is open Sunday 1-4 p.m. For more information, or to inquire about renting the Kemper Residence, call the Society at (540) 395-5119 or email madisonvahistory@gmail.com . The Carver 4-County Museum, located at The Carver Center, 9432 James Madison Highway, Suite 102, Rapidan, is open Friday and Saturday, 11 a.m. to 4 p.m. and by appointment. Contact C. Carpenter at (540) 270-3891. Groups welcome. The Madison Arts Exchange is hosting a free writer’s group the first Saturday of each month, 3-4:30 p.m. at 7353 S. Seminole Trail, Rochelle. The group moderator is local published author Susie McKenna. No experience necessary. Guests welcome. Open to adults and all writing styles. Bring a project in progress or an idea. Prepare to read three to four pages of your work out loud. General coaching encouraged, but not heavy critique. For more information, call 948-3300, email madartsX@gmail.com or visit madison-arts.com . The Madison County Farmers’ Market at the Hoover Ridge Park Picnic Pavilion runs through Oct. 26. The market takes place Saturday, 8-11:30 a.m. and has returned to on-site sales only to assure fresh, quality products. For more information visit madisonfarmersmarket.info . Friends of Wilderness Battlefield Interpreters will be giving tours of Payne's Farm weekends 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. June 8 - Aug. 11. Payne's Farm is located in Locust Grove across from Zoar Baptist Church (31334 Zoar Road) and is the site where a Civil War battle occurred during the Mine Run Campaign. The trail is wooded and good walking or hiking shoes are recommended. Visitors can walk the entire 1.5 mile trail or walk a quarter of a mile to view the field where the battle took place. The property is owned by the American Battlefield Trust and Friends of Wilderness Battlefield is working with the trust to preserve, promote and protect it. Tours are free; donations welcome. Graves Mountain Farm and Lodges will host the Graves Mountain Music Festival May 30 - June 2. Musical guests will take the stage Thursday, 4-9:30 p.m.; Friday, 2-9:30 p.m. and Saturday, 12-9:35 p.m. For more information and to purchase tickets, visit gravesmountainmusic.com/music-festival-lineup-2024 The first Virginia Black Bear Festival will be held June 1, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. on Main Street in Stanardsville. Talk to rangers from Shenandoah National Park, learn nature survival skills and chat with Smokey Bear. Or try fly fishing, archery, camping and cycling with outdoor sporting professionals. Participate in educational and interactive demonstrations led by experts from nature and wildlife organizations. Listen to professional storytelling, compete in the beard competition or bear hands arm wrestling challenge. Enjoy a porridge eating contest, live music and food trucks. Activities for all ages. Shop local vendors and artisans showcasing bear and nature-themed items. Admission is free; parking is at Greene County School just off Main Street. The Bidders for Critters Auction, to benefit MAD Cats, will continue through June 2 at 9 p.m. To participate, visit https://www.facebook.com/groups/2702710573354016/ . New items are added daily. The Bright Star Theatre will present “Greece Lightning” June 4 at 11 a.m. at the Madison County Library. The show features characters from Greece and the culture and customs of ancient Greeks. Learn myths and legends including Zeus and his Olympic friends, Poseidon and his ocean kingdom and the epic adventures of Hercules. VDOT will host a public hearing regarding the replacement of the bridge over the Hughes River on Rt. 729 (Moon Road) June 6, 5-7 p.m. at the Madison County Administration Building, 414 N. Main Street, Madison. On June 6 at 11 a.m. at the Madison County Library enjoy an instrument petting zoo featuring an opportunity to try out a variety of musical instruments. Author Susan Schwartz will discuss her book, "Haunted Charlottesville and Surrounding Counties," June 7, 5:30-7:30 p.m. at Revalation Vineyards. A portion of proceeds benefit the Literacy Council of Madison County. Four County Players will host auditions for "Putting it Together" by appointment only June 8 at Belmont Arts Collaborative and June 9 at Four County Players. Callbacks will be June 12 at Four County Players. Rehearsals will begin July 22 and be held Monday, Wednesday, Thursday and Friday, 7-10 p.m. in Charlottesville. Performances will be Aug. 30 and 31 and September 1, 6 and 7. Prepare up to 32 bars of a Sondeim song. Provide sheet music with clear start/stop points marked. For answers to questions, email auditions@fourcp.org . To RSVP, visit https://forms.gle/qYy4fnNV3r6PnJeJ8 On June 11 at 11 a.m. at the Madison County Library Uncle Henry will talk about “The Nature of Things in the Wind.” He will demonstrate a model sailboat and bring his famous ducks. The Madison County High School Class of 1974 will celebrate its 50th reunion June 15 at Graves Mountain Farm and Lodges’ Restaurant. Social hour will begin at 5 p.m. with dinner at 6 p.m. The $41 per person fee is due to Jayne by May 29 and can be mailed to 8919 Ginger Way Dr., Henrico, VA 23229. Plan to bring any memorabilia from school to share with all. Contact Jayne Penn Hollar for more details at jphollar@gmail.com or (540) 718-5430. On June 19 at 11 a.m. at the Madison County Library the Science Guys of Baltimore will present an interactive demonstration addressing Adventures in Science, Technology, Engineering and Math. Children will explode into a mission that reveals challenges of defying gravity and electrifying obstacles all while exploring science principles to navigate and escape. This adventure includes powerful forces of physics, stunning reaction in chemistry and more. Madison Parks and Recreation is hosting its Movies in the Park events for the seventh year from June through October. The movie nights are: June 21 at 9 p.m., “The Barbie Movie” sponsored by Madison Youth Cheer; July 26 at 9 p.m., “The Little Mermaid;” Aug. 9, “Trolls Band Together” with a bounce house and games at 5:30 p.m. and the movie, sponsored by Cowan Roofing, at 8:30 p.m.; Sept. 6 at 8 p.m. “Elemental;” and Oct. 19, “Wish” with games, costumes, activities and crafts from 4-6 p.m. and the movie at 6:30 p.m. The 2024 Music in the Park Summer Concert Series will be held at Hoover Ridge monthly June through August. The shows are: June 22, Brisk Band; July 27, Skip Castro Band and Aug. 24, Street Survivors—A Lynyrd Skynyrd Tribute. Shows are 5-9 p.m. with tickets $15 early bird and $20 at the gate. A summer pass for all three shows is available for $30. Music in the Park is sponsored by Plow & Hearth, Weaver Works and Nest Realty. For more information, or to purchase tickets, visit https://www.hooverridge.com/musicinthepark.html . On June 26 at 11 a.m. at the Madison County Library Spinny Johnson will combine basketball tricks learned during his Harlem Globetrotter years with character education. This will be a show filled with audience participation. On July 2 at 11 a.m. at the Madison County Library Wes Iseli will perform a magnificent magic show. On July 9 at 11 a.m. at the Madison County Library Virginia Wildlife will have an opossum, a reptile and a bird to share their characteristics and educate about how to protect and preserve wildlife. On July 11 at 11 a.m. at the Madison County Library Ms. Lillie will share storytelling and music as she engages the audience in dancing while exploring African roots. On July 16 at 11 a.m. at the Madison County Library the Bright Star Theatre will present "Storybook Tales." Enjoy the classic stories of Pinocchio and Robin Hood as the audience is invited to learn the importance of telling the truth and ways to help those in need. The Madison County Fireman's Parade will be held July 17 at 6:30 p.m. along Main Street. To enter a float in the parade, email tourism@madison-va.com with name, contact, phone number and a description. The Madison County Fair will be held July 17-20. Visit https://www.madisoncountyfairva.com for a complete schedule of events. On July 24, 10 a.m. to noon, the Madison County Library will host an end of the summer reading bash. Play on two giant water slides among other water activities, try a variety of outside play materials and enjoy snow cones. Guidelines: The deadline for submitting community calendar items is 3:30 p.m. Monday for that week’s paper. (The deadline moves to Friday before all major holiday weeks.) Items are subject to editing and may be sent via email to news@madison-news.com . They may also be sent by U.S. Mail to: Editor, Madison County Eagle, P.O. Box 325, Madison, VA 22727. Please include a contact person’s name and phone number. Due to the volume of items received, The Eagle cannot always run announcements from out-of-county organizations. title: John Wheeler: Bjerknes and Lorenz; the two most important names in meteorology
creator: John Wheeler
John Wheeler
description: Vilhelm Bjerkness developed the concept of weather systems and Edward Lorenz developed the weather model.
content: FARGO — The two most important names in meteorology and weather forecasting are Vilhelm Bjerknes and Edward Lorenz. In the early 1920s, the Norwegian Bjerknes developed the concept of a low pressure system forming as a disturbance along a zone of temperature contrast, with extended boundaries between contrasting air masses emanating from the low. He called them fronts after similar military boundaries in World War I. Edward Lorenz was a American mathematician and meteorologist who developed the method of using computers to solve systems of differential equations to forecast weather. He famously showed the issue with numerical prediction in a 1964 paper which showed that tiny changes to initial conditions in these equations would lead to massive changes over time. That is why even today’s very fast weather computers can reasonably predict weather short term, but are incapable of accurately predicting weather changes several weeks away.

title: Project Mercury company seeks incentive for $27 million investment in Greensboro
description: Greensboro and Guilford County elected officials are considering whether to approve performance-based incentive packages for what is known as “Project Mercury” for an industrial property in east Greensboro.
content: Greensboro and Guilford County elected officials are considering whether to approve performance-based incentive packages for what is known as “Project Mercury” for an industrial property in east Greensboro. The county Board of Commissioners appears to be the first to consider the economic-development project with a public hearing set for 5:30 p.m. June 6 in the Old County Courthouse at 301 W. Market St. in Greensboro. The unidentified company behind Project Mercury is requesting up to $373,855 in incentives from the county. It also is making incentive requests from Greensboro City Council and the N.C. Commerce Department, the latter involved because the company is considering locations out of North Carolina. In exchange, the company would commit to a $26.94 million capital investment and 80 jobs, both by Dec. 31, 2028, at 3617 McConnell Road. People are also reading... The prospective Class A industrial building is in McConnell Business Park and is being marketed for lease, along with 3655 McConnell Road, by the Triad office of CBRE. The 3617 McConnell building contains 104,629 square feet. The 3655 McConnell property features 120,368 square feet, while there is a proposed third building under consideration at 140,273 square feet. The site became available as an industrial site in June 2022 when a Cincinnati industrial real-estate firm paid $2.33 million to purchase a combined 35.88 acres. The properties were a 29.8-acre tract at 3635 McConnell Road and a 6.02-acre tract at 3617 McConnell Road. The buyer was McConnell Road Industrial I LLC, an affiliate of Al. Neyer of Cincinnati, which entered the North Carolina market in 2019 with an office in Raleigh. Al. Neyer’s listing of the McConnell property touts neighboring Coca-Cola, Vistar and Walmart facilities. “Central North Carolina has been the epicenter of a string of recent job announcements from major manufacturers, such as Toyota, Boom Supersonic, VinFast and Wolfspeed,” according to the listing. “The companies have unveiled plans to construct advanced manufacturing facilities that will employ more than 13,000 people. “The projects are expected to drive significant ancillary activity among suppliers and support industries, fueling future demand for industrial space across central North Carolina, including Greensboro.” Al. Neyer also lists Buckhorn Industrial Park in Mebane and Haw River Industrial Park in Graham among its other eight N.C. developments. rcraver@wsjournal.com 336-727-7376 @rcraverWSJ Get the latest local business news delivered FREE to your inbox weekly. {{description}} Email notifications are only sent once a day, and only if there are new matching items.

title: OneConnect Announces 2024 Annual General Meeting Results
description: SHENZHEN, China, May 28, 2024 /PRNewswire/ -- OneConnect Financial Technology Co., Ltd. ("OneConnect" or the "Company") (NYSE: OCFT and HKEX: 6638), a leading technology-as-a-service provider for financial services industry in China, today announced the results of its annual general...
content: , /PRNewswire/ -- OneConnect Financial Technology Co., Ltd. ("OneConnect" or the "Company") (NYSE: and HKEX: 6638), a leading technology-as-a-service provider for financial services industry in , today announced the results of its annual general meeting of shareholders held in on . At the meeting, the shareholders of OneConnect approved, ratified and/or confirmed the following resolution: OneConnect Financial Technology Co., Ltd. is a technology-as-a-service provider for financial services industry. The Company integrates extensive financial services industry expertise with market-leading technology to provide technology applications and technology-enabled business services to financial institutions. The integrated solutions and platform the Company provides include digital banking solution, digital insurance solution and Gamma Platform, which is a technology infrastructural platform for financial institutions. The Company's solutions enable its customers' digital transformations, which help them improve efficiency, enhance service quality, and reduce costs and risks. The Company has established long-term cooperation relationships with financial institutions to address their needs of digital transformation. The Company has also expanded its services to other participants in the value chain to support the digital transformation of financial services eco-system. In addition, the Company has successfully exported its technology solutions to overseas financial institutions. For more information, please visit ir.ocft.com. title: Spineart Receives 510(k) Clearance for SCARLET® AC-Ti Anterior Cervical Cage
description: GENEVA, May 28, 2024 /PRNewswire/ -- Spineart, a fast-growing company specialized in spine surgery, proudly announces the 510(k) clearance from the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) for its SCARLET® AC-Ti secured anterior cervical cage. The SCARLET® AC-Ti builds on a decade of...
content: , /PRNewswire/ -- Spineart, a fast-growing company specialized in spine surgery, proudly announces the 510(k) clearance from the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) for its SCARLET® AC-Ti secured anterior cervical cage. The SCARLET® AC-Ti builds on a decade of experience with the SCARLET® system. The SCARLET® AC-Ti addition introduces new features such as the MIMETIX® morphometric profile, developed with digital models of the vertebrae to optimize the contact surface between implant and endplates. The system allows for fixation with screws and anchors. The SCARLET® AC-Ti cervical cage utilizes Spineart's proprietary Ti-LIFE technology . Ti-LIFE technology, a proprietary additive manufacturing process, has a porous structure that closely mimics the trabecular bone structure. "This approval underscores our commitment to innovation, continuously evolving our most successful products, such as the SCARLET® system," said Alessia Erlingher, Chief Commercial Officer at Spineart. For more information about the SCARLET® AC-Ti cervical cage and Spineart's comprehensive range of spinal surgery solutions, visit For media inquiries or further information, please contact us at: . Spineart is a global company specialized in spine surgery innovation, dedicated to accelerating the adoption of cutting-edge technologies for surgeons and hospitals worldwide, for the benefit of their patients. Renowned for its commitment to Quality, Innovation, and Simplicity, Spineart continues to push the boundaries of spinal surgery with its comprehensive portfolio of procedural solutions and digital technologies. Spineart was awarded the "Prix de l'Economie Genevoise 2022" for its contribution to technological and scientific innovations, commercial activities, job creations and ESG principles. Visit and follow us on LinkedIn. , MD - Bradley J. Vivace, MD - Mónica López-Peña, DVM, PhD - Fernando Muñoz Guzón, DVM, PhD - Antonio Gonzalez-Cantalpeidra, DVM, PhD - Alberto JorgeMora, MD, PhD - - , PhD - , BS - , BS - Jesús Pino-Minguez, MD, PhD. 3D-printed titanium cages without bone graft outperform PEEK cages with autograft in an animal model. title: Fading 2023 VC performance underscores Canadian tech market’s “vulnerability,” BDC reports
creator: Josh Scott
description: Down rounds rose from seven percent in 2022 to 31 percent last year.The post Fading 2023 VC performance underscores Canadian tech market’s “vulnerability,” BDC reports first appeared on BetaKit.
content: Last year marked a “repeat year of recalibration” for Canada’s venture capital (VC) market as the industry continues to normalize following a , according to a study from the investment arm of the Business Development Bank of Canada ( ). Per BDC Capital’s latest Canadian VC landscape report, which was released today, 2023 also saw softening returns amid a proliferation of down rounds (a round of financing at a lower valuation than a company’s previous round) and markdowns for Canadian technology firms. As by the Canadian Venture Capital and Private Equity Association (CVCA), BDC noted that $6.9 billion CAD in VC funding was invested across 660 deals during 2023—declines of 34 percent and 12 percent year-over-year, respectively, as overall activity continued to return to pre-2020 levels. “After seeing VC activity come down from record levels in 2021 and witnessing interest rates reach new highs in 2023, the Canadian VC community was understandably feeling bleak last year,” the report states. “The numbers reported here, while not grim, underscore the ecosystem’s vulnerability.” As interest rates rose to the highest levels since 2001, there was pessimism heading into 2023. BDC’s charted declining VC activity, economic growth, and a “gloomy outlook.” But despite some cracks, BDC’s latest study found that this “worst-case scenario” did not come to pass. According to the report, 2023 “showcased both signs of resilience and fragility—some cautious optimism is warranted but must be tempered by persistent fundraising challenges and subdued returns.” The insights are based on analysis of data from CVCA, BDC, and PitchBook. BDC noted that macroeconomic headwinds have led to greater caution among VC fund limited partners (LPs) and general partners (GPs). In particular, “heightened diligence and caution” on the part of LPs has had an impact on Canadian GPs and tech entrepreneurs. LP influence has promoted discipline and improved standards among GPs and raised their expectations for portfolio companies, BDC claims. Amid a challenging fundraising environment, BDC reported that many VC fund GPs have not been able to achieve their first-close or final-close targets or raise funds at all. Across the board, fundraising is taking longer, the report found. The report also found that VC returns declined. In 2023, 10-year internal rates of return (IRR) for Canadian VC funds decreased to 11.7 percent, following a similar downward trajectory as United States (US) VC returns, while continuing to “gradually narrow the gap between the two countries’ long-term performance.” Meanwhile, BDC found that the one-year VC IRR for Canada dropped into negative territory, falling by more than 11 percent, “largely influenced by valuation corrections following the exuberance of 2021.” Contributing factors include an increase in down rounds and proactive adjustments by GPs. One-year IRR for VC globally also fell by a comparable amount in 2023, clocking in at the lowest among all private-capital asset classes. Ten-year VC net returns also dropped slightly but stayed in double digits last year at above 11 percent, while some vintages were also hit harder than others, the report found. For its part, the median distributed to paid-in capital improved across all vintages in 2023 save for 2020–2022, which remains young. The proportion of down rounds last year had an impact on these figures. Down rounds rose from seven percent in 2022 to 31 percent in 2023. BDC also found that in 2023, median cash runways got shorter, bridge financings declined, and venture debt funding lost steam. However, compared with global VC investment, Canadian VC experienced a slower decline in terms of total dollars invested in 2023. Per BDC, late and growth-stage investments were hit hard last year both in Canada and globally. VC put into late-stage Canadian companies was almost cut in half in 2023 relative to 2022, while the late-stage deal count dropped by 19 percent. By dollars invested, early-stage VC saw a smaller decline than later and growth stages. Sector-wise, the BDC reported that the life sciences and energy and clean technology (ECT) sectors demonstrated some strength in 2023. While the information and communication technology (ICT) sector still accounts for “the lion’s share” of VC investment, Canada has notably seen a “slight reallocation and increased investor interest” in life sciences and ECT, which both drew a larger share of total VC dollars invested last year than in 2022. At the same time, BDC identified “considerable gaps” at both the earliest and latest stages in the life sciences and energy and ECT in terms of active private Canadian VC funds backing pre-seed, seed, late VC, and growth equity-stage companies. The initial public market offering (IPO) market remained cool as only one Canadian VC-backed company— —went public via IPO in 2023, noted BDC. Meanwhile, mergers and acquisitions (M&A) reached record-high exit values last year, driven by a few large deals, including , , , and . For the second consecutive year, the report found over half of VC transactions in Canada included foreign participation. This indicates that investors from other countries, including the US, continued to consider Canadian VC an attractive asset class amid current market conditions. BDC estimates that Canadian-headquartered VC investors hold $10.4 billion in dry powder, or committed but unallocated capital. Citing PitchBook, BDC reported that as of last year, US VCs were sitting on a record $421 billion in dry powder. Speaking to the outlook for Canada’s VC market in 2024, BDC believes this data “reveals the possibility for slight optimism,” but acknowledged that challenges remain. “As the industry looks to demonstrate enduring profitability, the bar for new investment will be raised,” stated the report, which added that Canadian tech companies and GPs that are unable to meet these expectations will continue to face difficulties fundraising. If annual VC returns continue to drop for another year, BDC anticipates that average five-year and 10-year returns will likely drop to single digits. If that happens, BDC expects some institutional investors to reallocate more of their VC dollars to other asset classes. The report ultimately expressed hope that the Canadian VC market is returning to “a point of sustainable growth.” If anticipated interest-rate cuts come to fruition this year, BDC noted that M&A activity may increase, and the lower cost of capital may help sustain current VC activity.

title: Explainer: Fabricators essential in producing local steel for Bills stadium project
creator: Mike Petro News Business Reporter
description: Most of the companies in the state working on the steel beams for the Buffalo Bills new stadium project are custom steel fabricators. A fabricator takes the material from a steel mill and readies it for the worksite through the...
content: A ton of steel – roughly 25,000 tons – will be going into the new Buffalo Bills stadium. If this were another era, there’s a good chance most of it could come from steel mills in the Buffalo Niagara region. But those steel mills closed more than 40 years ago. In fact, there is little to no steel manufactured in mills in New York State anymore. Ironworkers assemble the steel frame of the new Bills stadium under construction in Orchard Park. There are at least 40 steel fabricators throughout New York, employing around 2,000 people, working on the project. That’s forcing the contractors building the $1.7 billion stadium to rely on steel made in other parts of the country for the massive stadium construction project. But state officials also note that there is still plenty of steel work being done by New York firms. They say about 60% of all the structural steel that will be used in building the stadium will be worked on in the state. That means a number of New York companies will play a role in the making, finishing and delivering of the steel used in the stadium, state officials said. But if there are few to no mills manufacturing steel left in the state, including in the once proud steelmaking Buffalo Niagara region, what does that 60% number touted by the state really mean? Essentially most of the companies in the state working on the steel beams for the stadium are custom steel fabricators. A fabricator takes the material from a steel mill and readies it for the worksite through the processes of cutting, bending, welding and assembling. They will take on tasks like figuring out where the bolt holes should be and building them into the steel. Fabricators play a critical role in a project of this size, said Brian Raff, vice president of sustainability for the nonprofit trade organization American Institute of Steel Construction, which represents both steel mills and fabricators. “Many times, the steel mills are only credited for this work, and I understand why that is because some people have never heard of structural steel fabricators, but their role is important in this project,” Raff said. “Most don’t understand the nuances of steelmaking.” The state is working with Cives Steel Co., a national firm headquartered in St. Lawrence, north of the Adirondacks, as the prime contractor for the steel fabrication work. Approximately 12,000 tons of steel – nearly half of what’s being used on the project – will be fabricated by Cives Steel. Your guide to the road to a new Bills stadium The company is among about a dozen fabricator facilities that are lined up for the stadium project. They also include JPW Structural Contracting in Syracuse and A&T Ironworks in New Rochelle. Local subcontractors working on the steel include Seneca Steel Erectors of West Seneca, Steel Tech Fabricators from Rochester, Huntress Painting of Niagara Falls and Interstate Steel Sales of Orchard Park. At least eight local unions representing laborers, carpenters, teamsters, engineers, plumbers, electricians and cement masons will be on the job while steel is being erected, state officials said. Additionally, Upstate Steel has been pursuing work on the stadium project after state economic development officials reversed their decision to exclude the Hamburg steelmaker from New York’s woman-owned business program. Led by Lauren Chmielowiec, the company’s president, Upstate Steel now operates a warehouse in an old Bethlehem Steel building. The steel these fabricators are working on is all being manufactured in the United States for one of the biggest construction projects ever in Western New York. “We wanted to see domestic steel, and we’re obviously looking for as much of the materials and labor to be as local as possible,” said Steven Ranalli, president of Erie County Stadium Corp., the state entity overseeing the project. About a year into the project, work is now being done on the second level of the new Bills stadium, continuing to rise from “the pit,” the deep hole that was dug to form its foundation. The steel is being used to build the skeleton of the open-air, 1.35 million-square-foot stadium that will seat over 60,000 fans and is expected to be completed before the start of the 2026 season. About a year into the project, work is now being done on the second level of the stadium, continuing to rise from “the pit,” the deep hole that was dug to form its foundation. Steel will go up level by level around the bowl, starting in the northwest corner of the stadium and proceeding to the southeast corner. The final level to be built will be level 5, which will consist of the stadium canopy 200 feet in the air. This summer, state officials expect about 1,500 workers a day will be on site as more steel goes up higher and some of the more detailed work gets underway. “These types of projects are a really big boost for the local economy and certainly New York’s economy,” Raff said. “And by employing all these people to support things like this stadium and critical infrastructure, I think steel fabrication contributes quite a bit to the local and state economies.” There are at least 40 steel fabricators throughout New York, employing around 2,000 people, and they work with many suppliers and other trades, creating additional jobs in these related fields, Raff said. That includes around 85 companies involved in painting the structural steel once it is fabricated, as well as others building in the columns or pillars on the beams, he added. By keeping steel fabrication local, there’s also savings on transportation costs and lowering emissions that come along with moving materials. “New York is a really big contributor to the steel construction environment,” Raff said. “We’re excited to see any high-profile project using structural steel so we’re following the stadium on the edge of our seat.” But overall steel production in New York isn’t what it used to be. These days, the state’s steel production is less than 1 million tons annually, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute. That pales in comparison with the nation’s leader in steel production, Indiana, which made more than 21 million tons of steel in 2022, and even the second highest steel producer, Ohio, with over 10 million tons of steel made that year. The steel being used at the stadium includes a green sustainability profile that makes this project environmentally friendly, Raff said. The production process, which no longer lives up to the trope of it being dingy and outdated, uses electric arc furnaces, emitting 75% less carbon dioxide than traditional methods at many foreign mills, he added. It contains mostly recycled material that comes from the steel of decommissioned bridges, buildings, appliances and automobiles. It gets melted down over and over and is continually made into new steel without any loss of durability or strength, Raff said. “It’s a really huge sustainability story for steel and a really good choice for this stadium,” Raff said.
